A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).

A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
Does the concept of a/an Map/Function need to be defined for a definition of a/an Law of Composition to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Law of Composition states that it is a map from the Cartesian product of a set $M$ with itself ($M \times M$) to the set $M$. This definition inherently uses the concept of a map or function, as it describes the law of composition as a specific type of map that takes pairs of elements from $M$ and assigns them to an element in $M$. Without the concept of a map or function, the mechanism by which elements of $M \times M$ are associated to elements of $M$ would not be defined or understood. Therefore, the concept of a map or function is essential for the definition of a law of composition to be meaningful and complete.
